./.title: Course Information
./.body:
Course Information
Official Course Name: Mastering the Microbiome(?) (any other official name?)
Meeting Schedule: Every __ and __ starting __ through ___ between 2:30 pm - 4:00 pm
Meeting Location: New Science Building  @ 435 East 30th St. conference room G19

Office Hours
Monday and Wednesday: 4:00 pm to 5:00 pm,  by appointment

Learning Objectives
Towards the end of this course the student will exhibit an understanding of contemporary microbiome research trends and analysis methods. The student will experienced the workflow of data analysis of the most popular platforms, will be able to understand their relative strenght and weaknesses. He/She will experience a typical microbiome project and will demonstrate mastery of analysis and critical thinking upon the results. Another main objective of the course is to communicate ____ results correctly and effectively.

first-question.html.title: Course Syllabus
first-question.html.body:
Course Syllabus:

Introduction
Understanding the (scope of the) impact of microbiome as a complex ecosystem on nature and human health specificaly.
Components of the microbiome - microbes, fungus, archeae , virome
Microorganisms characterization methods - history and contemporary


Sequencing technology
Classic Sangar sequencing
Pyrosequencing
Illumina Miseq
Future technologies (nanopores, etc)


Omics Data analysis

16S rRNA gene sequencing

Multidimensional scaling / dimension reduction 


Metagenomics

Meta-transcriptomic

Metabolomic



The Human Microbiome project (HMP) and (iHMP)

High-Performance Computing / Environment

HPC

Qiita

Galaxy cluster



Frontier topics in the research of the microbiome (too similar to aim I of introduction?)

Where do we use these technologies, what do we like to find?
Leading fields of microbiome research in human health:
Saving ancesteral microbiome from extinction
Restoration of gut microbial ecology by fecal transplantation
Age, Obesity
Autoimmune diseases (like T1D) and food allergies
Pregnanncy \  Embryonic development


The future of the microbiome research

introduction-ii.html.title: Introduction
introduction-ii.html.body:
This section aims to shed light on the impact of the microbiome on larger ecosystems in nature and human health specificaly.
This section aims to make you familier with the main components of the microbiome:

Microbes - microbiota
Archeae
Fungus
Virome

Design a successful microbiome study

Know your expected effect size. Know the number of variables you plan to control for. Plan your sample size 
Quality assurance - mock, positive and negative control
Minimize the confounding factors - the maternal effect or the founder effect [conducting a microbiome study]

Microorganisms characterization methods - history and contemporary

DGGE - denaturing gradient gel electrophoresis - Detect microbial infection in life-thretened indeviduals, food poisoning in fruits and meet (beef and polarty) 
Live cultures

second-question.html.title: Sequencing technology
second-question.html.body:
Sequencing technology:
Samples collection and analysis, an article.
Sangar technique basis:
Pyrosequencing  - 
454 developed an array-based pyrosequencing technology which has emerged as a platform for large-scale DNA sequencing. Roche announced the discontinuation of the 454 sequencing platform in 2013.
two approches:
a) sequencing by synthesis:
A DNA segment is amplified and the strand to serve as the Pyrosequencing template is biotinylated. After denaturation, the biotinylated single-stranded PCR amplicon is isolated and allowed to hybridize with a sequencing primer. Each incorporation event is accompanied by the release of pyrophosphate (PPi) in a quantity equimolar to the amount of incorporated nucleotide. ATP sulfurylase converts PPi to ATP in the presence of adenosine 5' phosphosulfate (APS). This ATP drives the luciferase-mediated conversion of luciferin to oxyluciferin that generates visible light in amounts that are proportional to the amount of ATP.
For more information: 
Large-scale DNA sequencing techniques
 QIAGEN website  
 Illumina technology

data-analysis.html.title: Omics Data analysis
data-analysis.html.body:
Qiime v2 - Quantitative Insights Into Microbial Ecology
The official site
Quality assurance - chimeras, sequencing quality filtering
QWRAP 



QIIME is an open-source bioinformatics pipeline for performing microbiome analysis from raw DNA sequencing data. QIIME is designed to take users from raw sequencing data generated on the Illumina or other platforms through publication quality graphics and statistics. This includes demultiplexing and quality filtering, OTU picking, taxonomic assignment, and phylogenetic reconstruction, and diversity analyses and visualizations. QIIME has been applied to studies based on billions of sequences from tens of thousands of samples.
